Posts.Content: econmom wrote: I am 2 months post surgery, BM with tissue expanders and left side axillary disection.  I find that on and off, I get achiness in my arms (mostly the left).  Stretching seems to help.  Some mild swelling on an off, but my left arm is dominant and bigger than the right arm to begin with. Anyone else experience this?  I am concerned it could be the beginning of LE.  I am getting my sleeve and glove on Wednesday from my LE therapist and I am hoping wearing it a bit each day might improve things. Liz DCIS w/ multi-focal IDC, neoadj. chemo, BM 11/12/08 with expanders, 28 rads Dx 5/23/2008, IDC, 1/7 nodes, ER+/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Achy arm econmom ehall

Posts.Content: econmom wrote: I found a lump in the shower on 4/27.  Mamo on 5/5, ultrasound on 5/9, biopsy on 5/20.  I was diagnosed on 5/23 with DCIS (< 2 cm) then an MRI-guided biopsy showed multi-focal IDC (too small for the mamogram) that is triple-negative and axillary lymph nodes are likely to be involved.  I am 39 with no family history of the disease.  My boys are 10 and 6.  Right now, I just pray for 10 years. I got a port today and will start neo adj. next week.  I know you are supposed to stay postive, but it is hard. DCIS w/ multi-focal IDC, neoadj. chemo, BM 11/12/08 with expanders, 28 rads Dx 5/23/2008, IDC, 1/7 nodes, ER+/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Joining the boards econmom omo

Posts.Content: econmom wrote: My bilateral mastectomy with expanders is categorized as a 23-hour outpatient procedure and scheduled for an outpatient surgery center.  Anyone else have this experience? I know mastectomy without immediate reconstruction is typically a 1-day stay, but I expected to be in a hospital. DCIS w/ multi-focal IDC, neoadj. chemo, BM 11/12/08 with expanders, 28 rads Dx 5/23/2008, IDC, 1/7 nodes, ER+/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Bilateral mastectomy as 23-hour outpatient econmom Scrappygrl

Posts.Content: Oct 22, 2008 12:34AM econmom wrote: I am just delurked to send hugs and vibes of support to all you ladies.  I began chemo in June, and just had my last treatment today:  4 DD A/D, 2 Taxol and 2 Taxotere (due to Taxol reaction). My chemo was neoadjuvant so I have a bilateral scheduled for mid-November, then likely radiation. You CAN do it! Now all I want for Christmas is some hair!
Posts.Title: Anyone starting chemo in October 08? SuzyWillKickThis unique

Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2009 02:56PM econmom wrote: Hi all, I am in a very similar position to posters here with neoadjuvant chemo, then the BM with expanders.  1/7 nodes was found to be positive.   I had great margins with the chest wall, and the IDC could not be found, but this is all post-chemo and rad guidelines seem to be geared towards women who have not had chemo yet.  With neoadj. chemo, I am left to assume that >4 nodes were originally positive and I should go ahead.  The radiologist admitted it is a borderline case, but my age (40) tips in favor of going ahead.  My PS has done many implant surgeries on radiated patients and was upfront about risks of failure, but, like Pam's PS, is pretty confident about a good result.    Liz
Posts.Title: Chest Wall Radiation and Reconstruction ninel 55andstillalive

Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2009 05:45PM econmom wrote: Hi Ninel, Well, one positive sentinel node and then 1 positive axillary node.  But this is post-chemo and on the MRI pre chemo my axilla lit up like a Christmas tree.   Also, when the IDC was biopsied it showed lymphovacular invasion.  The radiologist and others she consulted all agreed it is a borderline case, with the uncertainty being how many nodes were originally positive and the extent of the lymphovascular invasion of the IDC (as it was no longer present in the breast issue after chemo).  She told me if I were 60 years old, she would not recommend radiation, but at 40, she does.  I could really use a crystal ball. Liz
Posts.Title: Chest Wall Radiation and Reconstruction ninel 55andstillalive

Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2008 07:40PM econmom wrote: I had chemo for 4 months, then a bi-lateral mast. on 11/12.  One of two sentinel nodes +  and 1/7 nodes positive in the axilliary disection.  Additional chemo has not come up, but radiation is recommended, and I am starting in January.  What is weird is that the node cancer is ER+ while the IDC and DCIS biopsied tri neg.  Onc wants to do tamoxifen now, but I am not sure. On the brigh side, my IDC had an excellent response to chemo--35 sections of the affected breast and no sign of it!
Posts.Title: Node Pos after Chemo JanDun1 econmom

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2009 08:48PM econmom wrote: 4greatkids, You will get used to the expanders.  I had a BM with TE on 11/12/08.  I think it was about 2.5-3 weeks until I really felt better, and several fills later, I really do not find the TE that uncomfortable.  For me, the drains were the worst part--uncomfortable and just the idea of them--yuk! I have not had any fills since Janyart since I did 28 rads in Jan-Feb.  I see the PS in early June about more fills and exchange.
Posts.Title: just need a hug 4greatkids econmom

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2009 04:37PM econmom wrote: Beth, My situation was quite similar to yours--diagnosed at 39 with no family history.  A lump sent me to the doctor and with a regular needle biopsy she found DCIS, but suspected more.  So the MRI found suspicious areas on the same side and I had an MRI-guided biopsy on 6/5/2008.  The worst part of the biopsy itself was holding the same position for over an hour.  The injection of litocaine stings--like a bee sting for me, but I did not feel the biopsy itself.  I am nearing the end of this now--chemo from July-Oct, then BM in November, and now 16/28 rad treatments.  You can do this.
Posts.Title: Has anyone had a MRI guided biopsy bemurray Trickling

Posts.Content: Aug 25, 2011 10:07PM econmom wrote: Great post.  I am 3 years post diagnosis and could not agree more.
Posts.Title: 29-ish Months Post-Diagnosis: You Will Get Through This! Kaidog MNSusan

Posts.Content: Oct 22, 2008 08:18AM econmom wrote: Chemo does zap cancer in nodes.  I just finished neo-adj chemo yesterday and I will have an MRI next week, and a bilateral in mid-November.  Depending on the MRI results, the surgeon is considering a SNB and depending on those results, full axillary disection (left side, no cancer found on the right side).  She will do the SNB dye no matter what, as she likes to see the track of the node system in her patients. While I never had a definitive finding of cancer in the nodes (the needle biopsy of one palpable node came out negative), my left axilla "lit up like a Christmas tree" on the pre-chemo MRI.  I too am very worried about lymphedema, expecially because I am left-handed, so I am hoping to lose as few nodes as possible.
Posts.Title: Does chemo zap cancer in nodes... Lynette Maryiz
